abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Science Centers and
            Directed Research Phase I and Emergency Assistance Project
            is rated as satisfactory, sustainability as likely,
            institutional development impact as modest, Bank performance
            as satisfactory, and Borrower performance as unsatisfactory.
            Overall, this project achieved the main objectives. The main
            lessons learned include: The irregular funding flow
            resulting from federal budget management constraints and the
            complex fund transfer procedures adopted by the Project
            negatively affected the implementation of both the research
            projects and the Science Centers' construction
            schedule. Budget-management rules and the Studies and
            Projects Financing Agency's (FINEP) own operational
            structure were designed to deal with external loans, but not
            with grants. Some of the FINEP's financial intermediary
            arrangements were incompatible with efficient
            implementation. The call for competitive research funding
            were based on broad thematic lines, which led to wide range
            of thematic proposals. Eligibility criteria should therefore
            be more strict to encourage concentration and ensure
            solutions to very precise problems. The first call for
            proposals lacked integration and synergy with the Pilot
            Program as a whole. Mechanisms should be included in future
            directed research projects to make them more responsive to
            demand and help identify opportunities for greater synergy
            with program objectives.
